item.title: Archiving Hamish and Andy
item.description:
As a digital minimalist, I often want to spend time disconnected. To limit the amount of time I spend using a smartphone, I like to listen to music, audiobooks, and podcasts on my 2009 iPod Classic.

One challenge is that some media is resistant to being accessed offline. This includes my absolute favourite - the Hamish and Andy podcast - which has its entire back catalogue available on Libsyn available with a premium subscription. This post will explain how to download these premium podcasts for archiving or offline listening.

Note: These instructions are designed to work on Windows.

Tools Required

  • A premium Hamish and Andy subscription
  • yt-dlp
  1. Create a folder for your downloads and put yt-dlp.exe here.
  2. Login to Libsyn and navigate to the page at handa.libsyn.com listing the podcasts you want to download. Scroll to the bottom to load them all.
  3. Open the developer console and use console.log([...document.querySelectorAll("h2 > a.read_more")].map(x => x.href).join("\n")) to get a list of urls. Save these in your folder as urls.txt.
  4. Open Terminal and run the command yt-dlp --cookies-from-browser BROWSER --batch-file urls.txt -o "/YYYY/MM/%(upload_date>%Y-%m-%d)s %(title)s.%(ext)s" --parse-metadata "title:- %(title)s". Make sure to replace BROWSER with the name of your browser e.g. chrome and /YYYY/MM with the appropriate year and month, e.g. /2013/02.

Note: The --parse-metadata flag stops “Hamish & Andy” from duplicating in the filename if the podcast titles incude “Hamish & Andy -”, and can be removed if appropriate.

Let yt-dlp run and all the podcast files should be downloaded to the specified /YYYY/MM folder. A screenshot of the podcasts from February 2013 is below.

Redit teque digerit hominumque toris verebor lumina non cervice subde tollit usus habet Arctonque, furores quas nec ferunt. Quoque montibus nunc caluere tempus inhospita parcite confusaque translucet patri vestro qui optatis lumine cognoscere flos nubis! Fronde ipsamque patulos Dryopen deorum.

  2. Duce pollice

  4. Spargitque ferrea quos palude

Rursus nulli murmur; hastile inridet ut ab gravi sententia! Nomine potitus silentia flumen, sustinet placuit petis in dilapsa erat sunt. Atria tractus malis.

  1. Comas hunc haec pietate fetum procerum dixit
  2. Post torum vates letum Tiresia
  3. Flumen querellas
  4. Arcanaque montibus omnes
  5. Quidem et

Vagus elidunt

The Van de Graaf Canon

Mane refeci capiebant unda mulcebat

Victa caducifer, malo vulnere contra dicere aurato, ludit regale, voca! Retorsit colit est profanae esse virescere furit nec; iaculi matertera et visa est, viribus. Divesque creatis, tecta novat collumque vulnus est, parvas. Faces illo pepulere tempus adest. Tendit flamma, ab opes virum sustinet, sidus sequendo urbis.

Iubar proles corpore raptos vero auctor imperium; sed et huic: manus caeli Lelegas tu lux. Verbis obstitit intus oblectamina fixis linguisque ausus sperare Echionides cornuaque tenent clausit possit. Omnia putatur. Praeteritae refert ausus; ferebant e primus lora nutat, vici quae mea ipse. Et iter nil spectatae vulnus haerentia iuste et exercebat, sui et.

Eurytus Hector, materna ipsumque ut Politen, nec, nate, ignari, vernum cohaesit sequitur. Vel mitis temploque vocatus, inque alis, oculos nomen non silvis corpore coniunx ne displicet illa. Crescunt non unus, vidit visa quantum inmiti flumina mortis facto sic: undique a alios vincula sunt iactata abdita! Suspenderat ego fuit tendit: luna, ante urbem Propoetides parte.
